conclusion: To determine the magnitude of the electric field strength at point A of the cube, we need to analyze the contributions from the charges at points 2q and -q.

The cube has a side length L. The charges 2q and -q are located at two opposite vertices of the cube. The midpoint O of the line segment joining these two charges lies on the line connecting them, which is also the body diagonal of the cube.

premise: The distance between the charges 2q and -q is the length of the body diagonal of the cube.
conclusion: For a cube with side length L, the length of the body diagonal d is given by: d = L√3
The electric field E at a distance r from a point charge q is given by: E = ke |q|/r² where ke is the Coulomb constant.

premise: Since the charges are opposite in sign, the electric fields they produce will be in opposite directions.
conclusion: The net electric field at O is: E = ke q/3L²

premise: Given that the magnitude of the electric field at O is E, we have: E = ke q/3L²

conclusion: Point A is one of the vertices of the cube, and it is equidistant from both charges 2q and -q.

premise: The distance from each charge to point A is the face diagonal of the cube.
The electric field at point A due to each charge is: E2q = ke 2q/(L√2)²
The electric field at point A due to each charge is: E-q = ke |-q|/(L√2)²
Since the charges are opposite in sign, the electric fields they produce will be in opposite directions.
conclusion: The net electric field at A is: EA = ke q/2L²

premise: We know from the problem statement that: E = ke q/3L²
conclusion: Thus, the magnitude of the electric field at point A is: EA = ke q/2L²
